results.queryText: How does Boise's mayor-council government work?
results.responseText:
Hereâ€™s a clear, plain-English breakdown of how Boiseâ€™s mayorâ€“council government works and who does what.

ğŸ›ï¸ The Basics

Boise operates under a mayorâ€“council form of government, sometimes called a strong-mayor system. Power is split between an elected executive (the mayor) and an elected legislative body (the city council).

ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’¼ The Mayor (Executive Branch)

The mayor is the cityâ€™s chief executive and runs day-to-day operations.

What the mayor does:

Proposes the annual city budget

Appoints department directors (police, fire, public works, parks, etc.)

Enforces city laws and ordinances

Represents Boise publicly and in intergovernmental matters

Presides over City Council meetings

Votes only to break a tie on the council

Key point: The mayor manages the cityâ€™s administration and sets prioritiesâ€”but doesnâ€™t make laws alone.

ğŸ§‘â€âš–ï¸ City Council (Legislative Branch)

Boiseâ€™s City Council has six members, each elected from a geographic district.

What the council does:

Passes ordinances (local laws) and resolutions

Approves or amends the city budget

Sets citywide policy

Confirms certain mayoral appointments

Holds public hearings and takes public comment

Provides oversight of city operations

Council members do not manage departments; they legislate and oversee.

âš–ï¸ How Power Is Balanced

Think of it like this:

Role	Primary Power
Mayor	Executive leadership & administration
City Council	Laws, policy, budget approval
Mayor + Council	Budget adoption & major decisions

The mayor proposes, the council disposes (approves, modifies, or rejects).

Neither branch can fully act alone on major decisions.

This creates checks and balances at the city level.

ğŸ—³ï¸ Elections & Accountability

Mayor: Elected citywide

Council members: Elected by district

Elections are nonpartisan

Terms are staggered so not all seats turn over at once

Voters directly choose both the executive and the legislators.

ğŸ§  What This Means for Residents

Want to change policy or laws? â†’ Contact your council member

Concerned about how a department operates? â†’ Mayorâ€™s office or council oversight

Speaking at meetings mattersâ€”public comment is part of the process

Big decisions (housing, budgets, zoning changes) usually require both branches

ğŸ“Œ In one sentence

Boiseâ€™s mayorâ€“council system means the mayor runs the city, the council makes the laws, and major decisions require collaboration between the twoâ€”with voters holding both accountable.

How the budget moves from proposal to adoption

How residents can influence decisions at each stage

ğŸŒ² Environmental Pressures

ğŸ§­ Civic Trust & Engagement

results.queryText: What is Boise doing about homelessness?

With typical home values in Boise, annual property tax bills often fall in the low-to-mid several thousand dollars range. For example, with an effective tax rate near ~0.6% on a $400,000â€“$450,000 home, annual taxes often come in at roughly $2,400â€“$3,000 per year.

Each taxing districtâ€™s levy rate (county, city, school district, fire, library, etc.) is applied to that taxable value to produce your total tax bill.
